raw_text:
Beckham virus spotted on the net
 
 Virus writers are trading on interest in David Beckham to distribute their malicious wares.
 
 Messages are circulating widely that purport to have evidence of the England captain in a compromising position. But anyone visiting the website mentioned in the message will not see pictures of Mr Beckham but will have their computer infected by a virus. The pernicious program opens a backdoor on a computer so it can be controlled remotely by malicious hackers.
 
 The appearance of the Beckham Windows trojan is just another example in a long line of viruses that trade on interest in celebrities in an attempt to fuel their spread. Tennis player Anna Kournikova, popstars Britney Spears and Avril Lavigne as well as Arnold Schwarzenegger have all been used in the past to try to con people into opening infected files. The huge amount of interest in Mr Beckham and his private life and the large number of messages posted to discussion groups on the net might mean that the malicious program catches a lot of people out. "The public's appetite for salacious gossip about the private life of the Beckhams might lead some into an unpleasant computer infection," said Graham Cluley from anti-virus firm Sophos. Simply opening the message will not infect a user's PC. But anyone visiting the website it mentions who then downloads and opens the fake image file stored on that site will be infected. The program that installs itself is called the Hackarmy trojan and it tries to recruit PCs into so-called 'bot networks that are often used to distribute spam mail messages or to launch attacks across the web. Computers running Microsoft Windows 95, 98, 2000, NT and XP are vulnerable to this trojan. Many anti-virus programs have been able to detect this trojan since it first appeared early this year and have regularly been updated to catch new variants.
llama3.2:1b: Virus writers are trading on interest in David Beckham to distribute a malicious Windows Trojan, which opens a backdoor on infected computers by tricking users into downloading and opening a fake image file. The trojan, called Hackarmy, can infect computers running Microsoft Windows 95-XP and is designed to recruit PCs into "bot networks" used for spam mail or web attacks.
llama3.2:3b: Virus writers are distributing malicious content on the internet by exploiting interest in David Beckham, tricking users into opening infected files that install a Trojan virus called Hackarmy. The program can be controlled remotely by hackers and targets computers running Windows 95-XP.
gemma2:2b: A virus called Hackarmy is spreading via messages claiming to show compromising images of David Beckham. The message directs users to a website where the virus downloads and installs itself on a user's computer, opening backdoors for hackers. This type of virus follows a pattern used by other celebrities like Anna Kournikova and Britney Spears.  The virus specifically targets Windows computers and is considered malware.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Virus writers are targeting David Beckham's private life and public image in an attempt to make him a target for more malicious campaigns. The program, known as the Hackarmy trojan, aims to recruit people into bot networks that can be used for spam or web attacks. Some users may unknowingly open the message linked to this trojan by visiting the website mentioned in it. However, once an infected computer is opened, it will be subject to detection and removal of the malicious program.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Beckham virus spreads through celebrity-themed internet messages, exploiting public interest in David Beckham's private life for financial gain. The Trojan program opens a backdoor allowing remote control over infected computers. The virus targets Windows users and can be spread by visiting compromised websites that contain fake images. It is part of a trend where celebrities are used to distribute malware.
qwen2.5:3b: Beckham virus spotted on the net; virus writers capitalize on interest in David Beckham to spread maliciousware. Messages circulate about alleged compromising pictures of Beckham, but visitors end up with their computers infected by a trojan that opens a backdoor for remote control. Similar tactics have been used with celebrities like Anna Kournikova and Avril Lavigne. The Hackarmy trojan installs on vulnerable Windows systems (95, 98, 2000, NT, XP) and can be recruited into bot networks to distribute spam or attack websites. Many antivirus programs detect and block this virus.
opencoder:1.5b: The text presents a scenario where a malicious program has been discovered on the web by users who visit the website mentioned in the message. The virus can infect computers running Windows, and has also shown up for use against networks of bots or spam sources. It's intended to spread across multiple platforms but as it is a small-scale variant, it may not directly target public computers. However, if executed properly, it can neutralize or reduce the risk associated with cyber threats.
smollm:1.7b:
The Beckham virus is a type of malware that spreads through email attachments or infected websites. It's designed to trick users into opening the attachment or visiting the website, which then installs the malware on their computer. The malware can also spread through other means, such as file sharing and online communities where people discuss celebrities like David Beckham.

The virus is often referred to as a "trojan" because it disguises itself as something harmless, but actually contains malicious code that can cause harm to the user's computer. In this case, the malware appears to be related to the Beckham virus, which was first detected in 2005. The Beckham virus is still active today and has been known to spread through email attachments or infected websites.

The Beckham virus is just one example of a type of malware that uses celebrity appeal to trick users into opening malicious files or visiting infected websites. Other examples include the "Britney Spears" and "Arnold Schwarzenegger" viruses, which were used in the past to spread malware through email attachments or infected websites.

The appearance of the Beckham Windows trojan is just another example in a long line of malware that uses celebrity appeal to spread its malicious code. The virus appears to be related to the Beckham virus, but it's not the same thing. The Beckham virus was first detected in 2005 and has been known to spread through email attachments or infected websites.

The public's appetite for salacious gossip about the private life of celebrities might lead some into an unpleasant computer infection if they open a malicious file or visit a compromised website that contains the Beckham Windows trojan. The malware can cause harm to the user's computer by installing additional software, stealing personal data, or allowing hackers to access the infected computer remotely.

To protect against malware like the Beckham virus, it's essential to use strong anti-virus software and keep it up to date with the latest definitions. Users should also be cautious when opening email attachments or visiting websites that appear suspicious or contain links from unknown sources.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize the given text about Beckham's virus. The user provided a detailed passage, so my goal is to capture the key points while making sure not to include unnecessary details.

First, I'll read through each paragraph carefully to identify the main ideas. The first part talks about how viruses are created with the intent to target people's private lives. It mentions specific celebrities like David Beckham and mentions an example of a virus called the Beckham Windows trojan.

The second part describes how these viruses spread by circulating messages that claim someone has compromising power, leading users to get infected through their computer or downloading fake images. The explanation from Graham Cluley clarifies that while visiting such websites doesn't infect you, downloading files does.

I should focus on preserving the key elements: who created them (like David Beckham), the purpose (trying to capture others' private lives), how they spread (messages and downloads), and the type of virus (the Hackarmy trojan targeting Windows 95/NT versions). Also, mentioning Sophos's detection capability is important.

I need to make sure my summary is concise, avoiding any extra information or explanations. I'll structure it with a clear introduction, the main purpose, mechanism, examples, and conclusion.
</think>

Beckham Windows trojan was created to target interest in celebrities like David Beckham, using messages claiming compromising power. Users downloaded fake images from the website, which infected their computers through the virus. Graham Cluley explains that visiting the site doesn't infect your PC, but downloading files does. Sophos detects this trojan early and updates anti-virus software regularly.
tinyllama:1.1b: Unfortunately, the Beckham virus currently circulating on the internet has been found to spread by infecting users who open a malicious image file that is hosted on a website known to promote celebrity scandals. While it may not seem like a serious threat at first glance due to its innocuous-looking appearance, the virus could potentially install itself on your computer and gain control of your system if you visit the site mentioned in the message. Additionally, this trojan can spread through infected documents or attachments if they are opened with the click of a button. It is essential to avoid clicking on suspicious links or downloads from unfamiliar websites, as it may contain malware that could potentially compromise your system. The best way to prevent infection is by updating anti-virus software regularly and following common safety practices such as never sharing personal information or downloading files from unknown sources.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Beckham virus has spread rapidly across the internet by trading on interest in the England captain, David Beckham. This malicious software known as the Hackarmy trojan attaches itself to computers when they visit websites with messages about Mr Beckham, which then infects them. Once a computer is infected, it can be controlled from a remote location by attackers using this malware. The appearance of these viruses is just another way for criminals to exploit their target's interest in celebrities or public figures, and the large amount of attention given to Mr Beckham and his private life may contribute to making these attacks more successful.
phi:2.7b: The Beckham virus is a malicious program that spreads by trading on interest in David Beckham's private life. It infects computers when users visit a website claiming to have pictures of the captain in compromising positions. By opening these messages, users can install the Hackarmy trojan which installs itself on their computer and opens a backdoor for hackers to control it remotely. The virus is dangerous because many anti-virus programs do not detect it, and it uses bot networks to spread across the web. It has been around since early this year and is still evolving, making it difficult to protect against.
orca-mini:3b: David Beckham virus spotted on the net, virus writers use his private life to distribute malicious files. Messages claiming to have evidence of him in a compromising position circulate widely. However, anyone visiting the website mentioned will not see pictures of Mr Beckham but will have their computer infected by a virus that opens a backdoor and can be controlled remotely by malicious hackers. The program installs itself is called the Hackarmy trojan and tries to recruit PCs into bot networks used for spam mail messages or web attacks. Anti-virus programs detect this trojan since it first appeared early this year and have regularly been updated to catch new variants.
hermes3:3b: Beckham virus detected: spreading via celebrity interest, opens backdoor & allows remote control on infected PCs.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: A virus called Beckham Windows trojan spreads malware by using David Beckham's fame to trick people into downloading infected images. The virus opens a backdoor on computers, allowing malicious hackers to control them remotely. It affects Microsoft Windows 95, 98, 2000, NT, and XP and can be detected by many anti-virus programs. Simply opening the message is not enough to infect a user's computer; visiting the website and downloading the fake image file is needed for infection.
chatgpt-4o-latest: A virus disguised as a scandalous David Beckham image is spreading online, tricking users into visiting a website that infects their computers. The virus, a Windows trojan called Hackarmy, opens a backdoor for hackers to control infected PCs, potentially using them for spam distribution or cyberattacks. This tactic of exploiting celebrity interest has been used before with figures like Anna Kournikova and Britney Spears. While simply opening the message is not harmful, downloading and opening the fake image file triggers the infection. The trojan affects multiple Windows versions, but many anti-virus programs have been updated to detect and remove it.
stablelm2:1.6b: Virus writers capitalize on interest in celebrities like David Beckham to distribute their malicious software. Messages circulating online claim evidence of Beckham's compromising position but lead to website visits with potential computer infections from the Hackarmy trojan, which opens a backdoor for remote hacking. This is an example of phishing exploiting public fascination with celebrity lives and high numbers of messages posted on discussion groups on the internet. The virus primarily targets Windows users (Windows 7, 8, 10, NT, and XP) and is often detected by anti-virus programs as new variants emerge since its introduction earlier this year.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Celebrity viruses continue to exploit public fascination with high-profile figures for malicious purposes. A recent instance involves a Beckham Windows trojan circulating online, disguised as evidence of the England captain in a compromising situation. Users who click on messages and visit the suggested website are at risk of computer infection by this virus, dubbed Hackarmy. This program installs a backdoor, enabling remote hacker control. Previous examples include viruses linked to tennis player Anna Kournikova, popstars Britney Spears and Avril Lavigne, and actor Arnold Schwarzenegger. Despite the public's strong interest in Beckham's private life, anti-virus firm Sophos warns that simply opening the message does not infect users; only those who visit the site and download the fake image file are at risk. Computers on Microsoft Windows 95, 98, 2000, NT, and XP versions are vulnerable to this trojan, which attempts to enlist PCs in bot networks for spam distribution or web attacks. Anti-virus software has been effective in detecting and updating against new variants of the Hackarmy trojan since its emergence early this year.
